Description: Oval-shaped scaraboid (button seal?) carved from steatite; dome and plain back; underside incised with symmetric composition arranged vertically, representing stylised thicket of papyrus with central bud, addorsed volutes either side, and drooping stems with buds below; neb-basket sign underneath, detailed by incised vertical lines; device cut boldly into surface, surrounded with single line; large perforation runs through from top to bottom.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Button seals are usually produced between the Old and Middle Kingdom. The presence of such an early type of scaraboid in Naukratis can be interpreted in many ways: heirloom, brought from a nearby site in antiquity or by sebakhin, archaizing copy of the 25th or 26th dynasty… (on the various early scarabs from Naukratis see: Masson forthcoming). Another button seal decorated with a sema-tawy on its underside was discovered in Naukratis: Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H3710 (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 160). A similar thicket of papyrus decorates a cowroid with a patterned back, also found in Naukratis: BM 1888,0601.69 (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 159). For other examples of scaraboids with papyrus thicket decoration: Hornung and Staehelin 1976, pl. 90-91. Hornung, E., Staehelin, E. 1976. Skarabäen und andere Siegelamulette aus Basler Sammlungen, Ägyptische Denkmäler in der Schweiz I. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Egyptian Naukratis: the early evidence’, in A. Wodzińska (ed.), Delta and Sinai Current research, Proceedings of the conference in the University of Warsaw, Warsaw, April 25-27 2013.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OB.08) (phase 3)
Condition: Good, except for chip at one end and 'scar' where seal attached to display board
